reviewText:
I was originally given this game as a gift by a good friend of mine.

Usually, I don't tend to delve into Steam at all, I have been pro-console all of my life, until I played this game. After being a fan of simulation games on consoles (with the occasional PC port here and there) such as Football Manager, The Sims, Rollercoaster Tycoon to name but a few, I was skeptical going into playing this game, but boy was I wrong.

The game starts you out in a lowly garage with a start-up cost of 70K. Now to some, that is a lot of money to start of with in any game, (well, from your Garage at least) but taking into consideration the fact that it takes 8K a month to run the costs of everything, we can say it is justifiable. You also have the start-up option of running your games from a G64 (a hat-tip to the Commodore 64, which was obviously name changed due to copyright reasons) or the PC. There are also five game topics you are given to start-up with such as, Fantasy, Dungeon, Sports, Surgery and Military, but these can vary when starting up a new game, you could even get topics like Alien or UFO! It all depends on what the computer decides it wants you to have at the beginning.

You are able to unlock further topics by 'researching' them with the points you have accumulated for creating games, these points can also be spent on other things such as, improving the games engine, sound (or later on in the game) quests, among others. You are also given the option of choosing which marketable area you would like your game to go to once you have unlocked the 'Marketing' option once you have released enough titles to warrant these, or enough time has elapsed, there are split into three categories E (Everyone), M (Mature) or Y (Young), I only ever used the 'Everyone' option, but that worked well on every topic I did indeed choose.

As time progresses, you and the consoles around you do too, shortly into the game, the 'Ninvendo TES' (a homage to the Nintendo NES) comes onto the market, (which in some respects is a good thing as the consoles evolve, just like they did in real life) the G64 comes off of the market and later on you are introduced to other consoles, such as the in-game SNES, Master System, Playstation and eventually, the PS5 (the in-game names now allude me, I apologise).

Once you have reached the 1Million currency mark with creating games, you are offered to move into a bigger office, with much more space (I would personally advise this to be taken when you have about 10-20M in the bank, as you'll more than likely go bankrupt if you take this option too early on in the game). You accumulate the money by releasing good, titles (ratings with 7/8s are what I was getting until I released a Racing Simulator game which gave me 9s) which are rated by four gaming magazines. Now, if you're going for the achievements of 'Perfect Score' you are more than likely going to get it during the larger rooms, not necessarily in the Garage, I haven't personally seen it happen as of typing this.

Now, you should have enough money to advance to the next room, where you can employ people, a maximum of four is allowed in this room and this is where the fun starts to really kick in. You have the option of training them once you have employed them, if this doesn't happen, you will be stuck producing the same scored games for a while, also, switch up the genres once in a while too, its amazing how much a well researched game topic can jump from 4s to about 8s from the last time a game was made and a word to the wise, DO NOT make two game genres the same one after another, your fans will not like that and would probably end up losing some as well as money.

I could go further into the last room, but that is something that you need to find out for yourself to play, create your own consoles, release an AAA title and have up to 6 staff members, that is all I am going to let you in on there!

All in all, I would recommend this game to anybody and everybody and I am ashamed I never bought this myself and waited until I mentioned it to a friend to buy it for me as a gift, otherwise I would have bought it day one.

11/10.

Loved every minute of it and the achievements leave you wanting more.

reviewText: It is easy to learn how to play Game Dev Tycoon; figuring out how to maximise profits is a bit more difficult. You have to mix and match different genres to find what sells best. After you figure out what genres work well, you have to target an audience for your game. Then you have to decide what your going to work on more: gameplay or story? Dialogue or level design? Graphics or world design? In the end, all of your choices will be what makes or breaks your game.\n\nGame Dev Tycoon is definitely in my top ten favorite games. I have played many playthroughs and enjoyed each one. It is also relaxing to watch all of the design and tech bubbles float to the top of the screen. I would recommend Game Dev Tycoon to any of my friends.

reviewText:
In all honesty there have been few 'Tycoon' games I like.  I bought this title because, I want to be a game developer.   The Premise of Game Dev Tycoon is, rather... well you are a game developer, and you play through the ages and generations of video games, starting from the NES era of gaming and work your way through today.

The game progresses from you working alone in a garage, to a small team in a smaller office, to a massive corprate headquaters where you can pump out tripple A titles.

So the question is thus, what about the game development part.  Well basicly there are three parts to game development, and three sliders per part.  Pending on Genre and type of game pends on how the sliders need to be set, where you need to spend your time and resources into making a good game.  Then you watch bubbles (With one of the most addictive sound effects) float up into a compleation bar.  That's about it.

So in all honesty theres not much to gameplay at all, its simple, it's straight foward, and I quite like it, personally after hashing out a few sequals it makes you think on what you are creating, and has given me some neat ideas for games just because I kept pumping out sucessful sequals in this game.

So All in All, I recomend this game, it is a handy timewaster, it is fun in it's own way, a little addictive, and is easy on the CPU.  So by all means give it a whirl.

Note to the Developer: I think a demo of the first garage era would go a long way for this game to get more people to play it.

reviewText:
I put a great many hours into Kevin Toms' Software Star. I would invariably do extremely poorly, because using Hype was basically lying about how good your game was, wasn't it? That wouldn't be right. Tell the people the truth, they're only going to find out when someone hands them your game on a C90.

But I digress. THIS game is the same basic idea (Sim Games Dev) with a really pleasant presentation. Hire and fire, develop game features and engines, churn out cash-in franchises as often as you dare and throw as much marketing money around as possible to push you over the top.

It's essentially a toy for people who like games and gaming and the games industry and think about them a lot.

reviewText:
Gave Dev Tycoon lets you start your own company as a game developer. At first you start small in your garage, but as you make more and more successful games you can change offices, hire staff, and upgrade your skills through training.

While it is a simple concept, game dev tycoon is promising, in the sense that it keeps adding variety to your game making process and letting you make more complex choices as you progress through the game. The graphics and music are quite simple and not really an asset to be discussed for this game. Its gameplay largely consists of you adjusting sliders so as to decide which concepts you are going to give emphasis on while creating each game, such as sound, graphics etc. You also witness the emergence and disappearance of several types of consoles and decide where to release each game, while also keeping in mind the market trends.

The most prominent problem with this game, would be that you get to decide based on trial and error more often than not, and the feedback you get about the choices you made is not entirely helpful for you to choose better next time around. The existance of a wiki for this game has made it so that tons of people end up following just that, since it is way less frustrating to progress in this way. Overall, I wouldnt call game dev tycoon a bad game, but a game that could use some polishing to shine.

+ great genre/topic/platform variety
+ easy to grasp, hard to master


- game choice feedback is vague

reviewText:
Everyone reading this is a fan of playing video games, no matter the genre or topic of it. But I am positive that everyone reading this has also had the thought of creating their own games.

WELL NOW YOU CAN! In Game Dev Tycoon, you start from scratch as a 1980's indie game dev and work your way up to a AAA game company known worldwide. Control all parts of your business as you create games for everyone to enjoy.

This game is one of those where general knowledge can help when you first start the game. There's some obvious things that point out to you while playing (i.e Open World is important for RPGs) However, there's still a decent learning curve while playing this game, and even if you do something 100% like it says, you probably won't get a perfect score. Numerous things go into the making of a game. While content and gameplay is important, the year of the release, the system released to and even adding Basic Sounds can make all the difference. Heck I have 70+ hours as of editing this review and I went bankrupt on my last playthrough (Due to a mod ruining the flow of the game, excuses excuses.)

reviewText:
[Full review of Game Dev Tycoon]

Graphics:
The graphics are very basic but they're clean and go well with this type of indie game. However, I feel like the game would've benefitted from more customization options for characters and the actual businesses. The graphics are so simplistic that more customization probably would've been pretty easy to pull off, making it seem a little lazy. - 7/10

Audio:
I like the music but I'm pretty sure that there's only 2 or 3 tracks playing on a loop so it can get pretty repetitive if you play for hours at a time. The music that is there fits the game well though, I just wish there was more of it. - 7/10

Gameplay:
The gameplay is really unique and can get pretty complex, providing a great challenge for both new and veteran players. However, it can be a bit difficult to tell what was bad about certain games because specifics are not always offered and the review system has always seemed a little off to me.I think that there are enough unique aspects to keep the game engaging though, and you're able to hire on new team members to attempt larger games in the later stages, which are the most fun imo. - 8/10

Story:
There really isn't one. It's a typical tycoon game where the story is just one day you decided to start making video games and become successful" - nothing too deep. The cool thing is that you start making games in the very early stages of the gaming industry so you actually get to see all the “now-legendary” consoles released and make games for them! It can be pretty funny too since the developers had to come up with some pretty creative names in order to avoid copyright. A story isn’t really necessary in these types of games but it would’ve been nice to see your company presented with various choices or something. - 7/10

Replayability:
Like any tycoon game
date: you can play as many times as you want and it can also be pretty easy to fail so you might even have to start over a couple of times anyway. The beauty of a simple concept like this is that it never really gets old and I
hoursPlayed: keep the game installed on my PC just in case I'm ever in the mood to play it
voteText: which is pretty often honestly. I’ve completed the game a couple of times now and it’s always fun to play
helpfulPercent:
just don’t expect a totally new experience each time you play it. - 8/10

Overall:
Overall I was very impressed with this tycoon game
votesHelpful: especially considering the fact that it was made by a 2 man team and was released for the extremely low price of $10. There’s a lot of fun strategy to be had here
votesTotal: but only if you like the tycoon genre
votesFunny: and only if you actually have an interest in the gaming industry. If you’re bored by either of those two things
commentsCount: this game has nothing to offer you. Also
column16: there are mods for it now. - 7.4/10"

reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is a terrific, yet short simulation game. You start off just a single guy making games in a garage with a computer, and as you expand and grow you get the options of making game engines, hiring employees for certain jobs in creating in each game, making your own game console and creating a World of Warcraft rip-off called Planet of SurvivalCraft. Although this game is crammed with alot of content and fun, it really only lasts for 15-20 hours. You could probably speedrun this game in about 5-10 hours. I do only have 30 hours on this game, but I still recommend getting this game for a nice, burst of fun!

reviewText:
I have been playing video games since Asteroids, and I have alwas loved them.  Of course I have dreamed about making my own games at times.  So I just had to try this game.  I have played it a good bit, and I am not quite done playing it still.

The game follows the historical progression of gaming technology in a parodied way.   Instead of Xbox's it is all Ybox's and stuff like that.  In one way I enjoyed that because it takes you down memory lane.  Ah yes the fabled Dreamcast.  However it also left me knowing what to expect.  I didn't bother buying licenses to produce on certain platforms because I already knew those platforms were not a big sucess in the real world.

The trailer says create games your way."  You can do that
date: but they'll flop.  This game seems to have a fairly narrow view of what kinds of games will be successesful.  Although it's entirely possible I just have not figured out how to break out of the mold.  It's ironic because the devolpers of this game are thinking out of the box somewhat with their game about thinking within the box of of what maybe EA games would tell their staff to make.  Just like the historical technology in the game
recommended: the definition of what can be a success also appears to be tied to gaming history.\n\nThey have opened this up to the workshop
hoursPlayed: so that's really cool.  I haven't used it yet
voteText:
but am excited to see where it takes the game.

Even with my reservations I really do like the game.  It is a fun simulation and it is challenging.  I'll make my company grow for a while only to run afoul with a couple flops and then be strapped for cash.  It keeps me wanting to try again.
I think it is a fair price and would be a good addition for anyone who likes simulations or is interested in the history of gaming.  Also worth mentioning is that the game has a good bit of educational value as well.  It teaches bits of finance and company management.  Good game!"

reviewText:
Strangely really fun! Bought it because it was on sale and as a software developer myself, I wanted to see if I could live the dream in a virtual world :)
The concept is really simple and it's repetitive BUT the repetitive actions occur fast and have consequences which you need to quickly adapt to in order to avoid going bankrupt, which keeps you on your toes.
You start in your garage and you have to research concepts, teach yourself different skills to develop, decide which consoles (N64, Gameboy, Playstation, PC, etc) you are going to develop games on etc.
It's really nice to just play in windowed mode and enjoy a few clicks every now and then. Definitely worth every penny based on the current Summer Sale price.
The welcome message from the dev team was nice too :)

reviewText:
As an Indie game, this is not bad.

I'm a fan of the original Tycoon games, so it's safe for me to say that this Indie game made it pretty far. If you think about it, it's not about the graphics or music - it's about the strategy and the satisfaction you get from that successful achievement of being, well, successful. This is one feeling we all have deep down inside and it can come from anywhere, real life scenarios, or video games.

Rather you're fishing and finally got a hook, or moving to the next stage in this game it's the same feeling of accomplishment. The only thing the game lacks is maybe a higher time frame between console releases. It seems to be a little too fast-paced when you're actually sitting here playing it. This game could also use a meter on how fast you'd like time to pass rather it's real-time or 100x faster for example.

Pros:
-Addictive gameplay
-Allows your creativity to fly
-Good engine
-Basic controls (Rather you're a gaming veteran or a newcomer, anyone can play with ease)

Cons:
-No control on the time flow
-You'll mostly always feel rushed
-Could use some more tweaking

Overall, I'd give this a 8/10. I can tell this took some time to actually develop - as I said before it's not about the graphics or music that made this the game it is today, it's the gameplay. From what I can tell, it took awhile to actually make this game fully functional which needs to be credited. This could be a text-based game and I'd still enjoy it.

Would I recommend it? Maybe, I wouldn't say $10 USD would be worth Game Dev Tycoon, however I'd say around the $4.99 or lower range (on sale) would be reasonable. Some have regrets about buying this game, you need to give it time or maybe start over. The point is, have fun.

reviewText:
REVIEW FOR GAME DEV TYCOON:
Game Dev Tycoon is a game I really wanted when I played it as a kid. So very recently, I've got myself my first Steam Acount and played only Level 1 of this game. So was the game good as I remembered it when I played the DEMO or a waste of time?
Sounds:
So the music sounds okay. I can hum a few tones from the game.  6/10
Gameplay:
So this is a business tycoon game. A really popular concept. Now I've heard that there is another Game Dev Game, but I think that this game is better. Plus I'd never played the other one people talk about. You are going around making games and getting fans and money. And if you make a hit game, you may get an office. Now I haven't played the office yet, but holy crap is this game fun.

It also makes you think sometimes. If I had a few flaws, when you start the game you may get a white screen unless you clear the cache or something. Also it is pretty hard to come up with some ideas but that is a realsitc concept so maybe I am bashing it for what it is. The games really fun and I think you should play it! 8/10
Story:
The Story is just epic. While I don't think younger gamers would really understand it (unless they look in the history books), it well be faithful to some gamers. Due to copyright issues they changed the company's names but you can get an easter egg if you type one of the Offical Names. I hope it gets better! 9/10
Graphics:
They look pretty darn good. They look very smooth and maybe a little generic but I don't have a lot of complaints. 7/10
Replay?:
This game is something that you may play a few times after 43 years in the game. It could be very fun to create a ton of games. And maybe you would like story. Just to be fair I will give Replay: 7/10
Is this game Good?:
Yes it is! It is a game that I think every video gamer should play unless they hate tycoon business games. It is fun and faithful to gaming. I'll give this game 8/10 A must buy!

reviewText: Holy crap is this game addictive. Grabbed it during the Holiday sale and do not regret my decision. This game is pretty darn accurate as far as the video game industry works. Sure, it's just a simple simulator but you have to make decisions based off what gamers will like in the game that you are developing which cannot be taken lightly. It takes awhile to get used to the fast-patced mechanics and hectic lifestyle of a developer. You must pay attention to every detail when making a game and make sure that what you are developing is top-notch or otherwise the game will flop.\n\nIf you fail a few times and go bankrupt in the game, learn from your mistakes and try again. This game is super addictive if you think you know what it takes to develop a AAA title game and please the critics :)

reviewText: I was very excited to see this game come on sale recently, as I'd had my eye on it for some time. It is a very good game at first, despite a lack of polish here and there (inexplicable error message on first launch, the odd spelling/grammatical error in the dialog boxes, etc.). Therefore, I think it is worth getting on sale.\n\nHowever, it quickly gets old; mostly, I think, due to its cyclical mechanics and unrealistic time scale. As a simulator, these factors take away from the experience. For example, a game may take as little as several months to produce, bug-free, and is on the market" for only a short time
date: even if it is a smash hit. The result is that you must constantly churn out game after game

reviewText:
The WarZ of Game Dev games.

Beat over 2 days. Really fun at first, but when you read articles and reviews about this game, you'll find out that this game is a HUGE RIPOFF from Game Dev Story (Developed by Kairosoft for the PC in 1997, ported to Android and iOS in 2010).

Developers of Game Dev Tycoon claim that Game Dev Story had a major influence of this game, but on the other hand said it was made from scratch (which should include ideas of the game, gameplay, and audio...) when comparing the two Game Dev Tycoon looks, feels and has very similiar experience to Game Dev Story, even with the music.



Game Dev Tycoon is a good substitute for Game Dev Story. The original game.

reviewText:
One of those games where you don't expect much and then it surprises you. Yes, the core gameplay mechanics may be around sliders and yes, at late stages when you have R&D/hardware lab researching something it may lag here and there even on high-end PC-s but put a little imagination in it and it will entertain you more than 90% of today's AAA-s.

To re-create some of the most memorable titles is really priceless, there are easter eggs and some amazing feelings of satisfaction as you get successful. Also, I would recommend some mods for expanding the game even further. At the price, it's not spending. It's investing into some nostalgic gaming moments. Just plain and simple fun.

86/100

reviewText: Pick the perfect combination of concept, genre, and platform (while managing marketing, budget, and personnel), and you could have the next gaming sensation on your hands.\n\nGame Dev Tycoon is a fun business sim with plenty of inside jokes for anyone who follows the gaming industry. Graphics and sound are quirky (in a good way), the interface in unintrusive and functions rather smoothly, and gameplay is entertaining. My major criticism would be a lack of replay value; after you've successfully completed a 35-year career
date: I'm not sure there's much reason to return for a second pass at the game.\n\nNevertheless, that first trip through the game consumes a solid five or six hours of gameplay -- during which I never found myself bored. Overall, Game Dev Tycoon is well worth the price of admission, especially if you can pick it up on sale.

reviewText: This was one of the best indie games I've played in a long time, if not ever. If you're a fan of simulation games/tycoon style games, this one will be right up your alley. The game starts basically at the dawn of early gaming starting at the Commodore 64 (renamed G64) and PC, working all the way down history to the Xbox One, PS4 and even simulating new future" consoles.\n\nYour goal is simple: make quality games and lots of money to move out of your garage and eventually start your own game studio. Trying out new genre combinations for games is interesting and deciding where to allocate your resources for best effect (for example
date: you generally want to go with Fantasy for making an RPG game
recommended: Military for Action games etc). Eventually the process gets more and more involved as you have to assign team members to work on games and train their individual strengths deeper. Eventually you can create MMORPGs and "research" projects like a Steam-based platform
hoursPlayed: and even develop your own console so the game depth only increases as you go along.\n\nMy only gripes with the game is sometimes critics will be all over the place in regards to their scores. When creating what you thought was an AAA title
voteText: they may only end up rating a 7-8
helpfulPercent: whereas a title you didn't put as much money into
votesHelpful: might score 9-10s. Critic score generally dictates how much your game is expected to sell. Also
votesTotal: you move through the eras a bit too quickly
votesFunny: as I completed the game before I was even able to start researching some advanced technologies (like Steam). Though
commentsCount: you could chalk that up to it being my first playthrough.\n\nOverall
column16: you're likely to get 6-7 hours out of it your first playthrough assuming you make it to the end without bankruptcy. There isn't a whole lot of replay value but if you're an avid gamer
column17: it's definitely worth it on sale alone for the tongue-in-cheek gaming humor and entertaining gameplay!"

reviewText:
So you're sitting there in your garage trying to make it big. Video games haven't even developed shading yet, but you're still giving it your all and trying your best. You make a few good games, a few bad ones. You veer dangerously close to the line of poverty and you bite your fingernails in anticipation of the inevitable failure that is sure to consume you. But then..

It happens.

You make that game. Maybe it's a game about butts evolving into aliens and attacking people. Maybe it's the most sophisticated, most complex idea you've ever mustered up and you may have just crossed the intellectual threshold into ascendance and are on your way towards demigod status. But you do it. You choose that magical Genre/Topic combination, you slide those sliders into juuuust the right spot, and then you watch the reviews.

10's. Maybe some 9's. Your jaw drops and your eyes open wide. You look towards the income menu and see hundreds upon thousands of people are buying your game. 100k. 400k. 750k. You hit one million dollars and it just keeps going and then you realize..

That was just one game. You're still in a dingy garage. You have to make more. You have to be better. You get a notification that a new office has opened up and is ready just for you and your company. With the most trepidation you've felt since your first day at school, you accept and move on. Taking it all in, you now begin to realize the daunting truth that has now gripped you by the throat. You're hooked. Can't quit now. You have games to make.

This is Game Dev Tycoon.

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon, as the title says, is a Game Development Tycoon. Its a fun game in which you can develop your own company, produce games and consoles and make millions.

Pro:
-Good mechanics.
-Streamlined menus for easy selection.
-Its fun making games and consoles.
-Its great seeing that your game got a 11/10 and made millions.
-Lots of research and development options.
-Mod support was recently added.
-Translations to other languages. Multiple translation projects are going on and some are already finished.

Cons:
-You sadly can't make any boxart for games but thats not that bad.
-The game slows down dramatically when alot of things are going on. Its really irritating.
-Not everything is clearly explained. You need to work it out yourself or read a guide.

This is a really good tycoon game and I recommend it if you like tycoon games.
I give it a 8/10.

reviewText:
Yes, I know this is a improved copy of the iOS game, Game Dev Story, I had it and probably spent 100s of hours on a tiny screen. But I'm not reviewing that, I'm reviewing Game Dev Tycoon, by Greenheart studios, not by Kairosoft. Although it's not Game Dev Story, it still is one of the more fun games I have played.
You play as a guy/girl who starts their own buisness in their garage, with only 70k (I think :P) and a computed (And maybe a car that's half covered). You must create multiple games until you move up a stage and make a buisness with workers and so on and so forth. Since this game was released, you can now generate a game report, which tells you what you did right, what you did wrong and what you could do to make it better. I know I only have spent a couple of hours, but the game is still amazing and although I've started multiple times, I've never been annoyed with starting over, because I want to see where I went wrong to go bankrupt and how I should change that.

The Good:
-Addictive gameplay
-Fun combinations
-Never-ending gameplay
-Funny company names (Like, Ninvento or Vonny)

The Bad:
-Lack of genres
- Reviewers suck sometimes

Overall score:
8/10

reviewText:
This game is quite a little gem. For the first game that came out by the Greenheart Games developer, they did spot on. Going through the years and seeing the game industry change from a developer standpoint (all be it their off brand versions. i.e. Vonny = Sony) and even getting to develop your own console at some point is massive fun. It's can be very challenging trying to figure out their interpretation of various genres and play styles, and getting that 10/10 on a game feels very rewarding. They even go so far as to incorporate MMO's, sequels, and expansion packs, all with roughly accurate feelings of how their development and distribution is perceived.

Very eager to see if they come out with a sequel, as there are a ton of features I would like to see implemented and current ones that I would love to see expanded. For instance, basic and advanced accounting statistics, expanded skills and point values, and a feedback system for your games, just to name a few.

Awesome game, played the hell out of it and would recommend it to anyone who wants a game to just chillax a bit.

reviewText:
Recommended if you get it for free / dirt cheap

Similar to Game Dev Story (Android/iOS game) and all other KairoSofts games. The main difference is that Game Dev Tycoon has much less depth. There is not much of a side-mission other than to grind games.

Fun for a few hours wtih little to no replay value. After one play-through it's not that much fun to do everything from scratch again. Even with the legacy research and the possibility of trying different genres.
The same genres will reach success in each play-through, the same tech will be researched, etc.

It is a cute (visually) little game with decent soundtrack and some fun dialogues written into it. But as a management/sim game it does not go far.

reviewText:
This game is extremely fun.  You start out as a 1 man developer in the garage of your mother's house.  As you increase your ability as a developer you increase your stats of technology and design, which allows you to make better games.  As you make better games you make more money, which allows you to upgrade from your garage into offices.  Once you enter the realm of being a professional developer in offices you are able to hire employees and designate their responsibilities from design to technology to research.  All of it works together to allow you to keep upgrading your office, employees, and games.

This game has a way of keeping you hooked.  You get so focused on making sure your next game release is better then your last.  Before you know it, hours have passed and you have work in the morning.

I highly recommend this game.  The price makes this game a no-brainer purchase.
voteText: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I've been playing this game for only a day, and I already want to have its babies. It's the first game in two months that made me stay up late so I could keep playing it. The mechanics are simple and easy to understand, allowing you to get right to the important business of building and customizing your games. And when you finally get that first 10 rating, and that first million bucks, everything has been worth it. Greatly looking forward to sequels/updates/mods/finishing the game.

-----

This is five weeks and 40 hours of additional gameplay after that first paragraph. I still recommend this game, but with a lot less enthusiasm. The game gets very repetitive after a while, especially because financial success hinges on putting out one near-perfect game every few years or so, with everything else just being filler. I absolutely hope there's a bigger badder sequel in a year or two, one that addresses the following issues:

Idiot Publishers: Your mid-game is overly dependent on using publishers so you can make larger games for more money and fans. But more often than not the publisher will either ask for a game you haven't researched, a format you don't have rights to, or a terrible topic/genre combo. I get that it's supposed to make you take chances and expand your options, but if I'm desperate and need a medium game fast, I'd like to actually be able to make one.
Employee Stagnation: In order for their skills to improve, your employees must train. Making games gives them nothing; you MUST spend time and research points and capitol on boosting their skills. And you have to do this a lot, which means that you can't be constantly working on games - or researching new topics/engine elements.
Chronic Indie Mindset: Even once you hit the late game and become an industry juggernaut, it's still just seven dudes cranking out a game. Yes, you can eventually develop a hardware lab and an R&D department, but they don't directly assist in game-making. I want to become a monster, with dozens - or even hundreds - of employees, making multiple games at once, training some people while others are dedicated to improving my engine and so on.
Research Bottleneck: As mentioned above, you need research points to train employees as well as to research new topics and game engine elements. The only way to generate RP for most of the game is to make more games, a newer engine, or generate a game report. As such, you often end up falling behind in either training or engine (or god forbid, both) as you struggle to devote enough points to their multiple needs. I'd recommend being able to create an R&D lab much sooner, thus giving the player many more points to work with, rather than reducing point requirements.
Hardware Focused: When I first started playing, I really loved how the game told the history of gaming consoles, as it's not something you hear about a lot when researching gaming history. But consoles are almost exclusively the only outside influence on your game-making. Nothing about software or legal battles or any of that. Just console development. And while interesting, it's such a small part of the story.
Forced Conformity: One of this game's mechanics has you matching game topics to genres; the better the match, the better it sells. In other words, you can't make a unique game. For example, according to GDT, Prison/RPG is an okay combination. But what if I want to make a stellar Prison/RPG? Instead of just stating that such-and-such a combination is good or bad, it should be up to the player to make it good or bad. Also, the entire nation of Japan would like to say something about Romance/RPG not being a great combination; I have 60 hours of gameplay and that still messes me up.

And yet despite all those flaws, it's still an enjoyable game. In my last playthrough I jokingly made a Vampire RPG called Count of Calypso and it got me out of the basement. The three sequels got me into the final game stage, paid for my R&D lab and new game engine, and became the game I was known for, respectively. I created the Fallout franchise with the help of Dave Johnson, head of Departure Science. Tom Schoffer is somehow a tech genius and became my first AI specialist. I made Half-Life, Half-Life 2, and won the game before I could releas Half-Life 3. There are so many good stories that come out of Game Dev Tycoon; I just wish it were less frustrating to create them.

reviewText:
One of the best tycoon/simulation games around.

I can't recommend this game enough to anyone who's into such games. It's a relatively simple game, but it's pretty addicting once you get into it.

You can not only make your own games (there's a variety of genres that you can mix and match to your heart's delight; even more with the Steam Workshop) but your own game consoles (even more of them too with Steam Workshop) as well. You can even make your own version of Steam in game.

From a humble setting (a garage in the 1980s), this game offers you the chance to forge your own way through gaming history and I've had a blast doing exactly that.

Whether full price or on sale, I wholly recommend getting this game.

And Greenheart, I saw your thank you message in game. You're very welcome.

reviewText:
Started a company called Steam, released a console and got pelters until I was out of business !!!! hahahahaha

On a serious note this game is actually quite imersive. The graphics while somewhat simple are actually quite a nice touch. In many respects this is not too disimilar to many other Tycoon based games. There are some really nice touches like how the pcitures of the different cosnoles acrtually look like the ones we all knew and loved (original NES, SNES, Master System ect). Overall the game is quite addicitve, especially once you get into developing and releasing MMO's and expansions.

For the price its well worth picking up. It does have its moments, but I think once you have played it thorugh a few times you are probably done. Certainly not a timeless classic, but none the less a decent tycoon / sim game which you should get a few weeks of enjoyment out of. There are some mods you can get from the steam workshop which would probably add a bit more longevity to the overall expereince so well worth going there and checking them out. Only had this a few days, but I do like it.

In a nutshell its simply, quirky and fairly addicitive in the short term.

reviewText:
This game is pure crack!

I had no idea such simple game mechanics (basicly using sliders) and micro managment could keep me so interested for such a long period of time.

Game Dev Tycoon is solid proof 2 guys in a basement can make better games than some AAA" titles out there.

This game holds some very interesting gaming history (you progress through 35 years. once they're done you finish the game).

Wonderful sense of personal growth - you start off as 1 guy in a basement and end up 7 people in a fancy office building.

Game Dev Tycoon helps non game developers understand some basic game creation modules
date: such as game engine and what the hell are contracts
recommended: which I found very interesting and informative.\n\nAlso
hoursPlayed: this game holds more depth and choice variety than first meets the eye
voteText:
I'm impressed.

Important notes:
- The game ends after 35 years (eventhough you can keep playing the same run).
- You get to keep your learned knowledge from previous runs in case you decide to start again -

Two cons I can think of:
1. Slightly high price (considering the simple game mechanics).
This feels more like a $5 title than a $10 title.
However I bought it at nearly full price to support the developers and its well worth it.

2. Repetetive music - If only they'd get more music variety instead of the same couple of 2 minute tracks on repeat.

This is the only game in the world that guilt trips piracy! They get bonus points for that :)

TL;DR - Great game
helpfulPercent: addictive as hell
votesHelpful: BUY IT! 9/10."

reviewText:
A very enjoyable game. The tutorial is short and simple and gets you right into the action. The menus are well designed and there is not much clutter on the screen.

The social commentary and satire on the video game industry is great at times. The main problem this game faces is that after you have beaten it a few times nothing will really surprise you. Even then you will get hours of enjoyment from the game.

I would purchase if you have looked at the screenshots and thought it looked like fun. Well worth the price... this game is a quality game at a bargain bin price.

reviewText:
This game is friggin' ADDICTING!!! I get lost for hours upon hours and it stays fun and exciting the entire time, the visuals are cute and simple but the core of this game is what makes it one of best PC games I've ever played, it truely is the pinnacle of how fancy graphics are not needed to make a perfect game.

I grew up with Atari, Apple II, Commedore 64, NES, SEGA, etc.etc. so this game just pours on the nostolgia with the sounds and style plus the hilarious alternative universe gaming console lineup for you to develop on, create your own world at your own pace and develop games you always wanted or you can play it like real history, pretend you were on the ground floor of Valve, Sega, Nintendo, Sony or Microsoft, create the top games of all time and see how filthy rich you can get while having a blast + training your brain all at the same time!

I have absolutely nothing bad to say about this game, instant classic and one of my all time favorite games.

11/10 - it's that good!

reviewText:
A forgettably bland spreadsheet simulator. While many games can be reduced to the math to some extent, the art of hiding this, or simply increasing the complexity to the point where optimization is no longer feasible due to multiple constraints and varying situations, is crucial.

Game Dev Tycoon has nothing to do with making games. It is solely concerned with making the player drag around a set of sliders to find the optimal combinations, in the pursuit of ever larger numbers. The window-dressing of a game development studio is immaterial, as it impacts precisely nothing.

This is not to say that it is a bad spreadsheet, in and of itself. The game is perfectly functional, and the puzzle of searching for ideal combinations might satisfy an evening, or more for the kind of person that enjoys the optimization challenge. However anyone who does not find such appealing would be well advised to find something else to do with their time.

reviewText: I've only played this game for about 10 hours and it's made an amazingly addictive game.  PREMIS: You a game developer (starting out in a garage) who starts their game dev career in the early 1980s. You go through to about 30 to 40 years. In that time you upgrade your HQ add other game devs to your team. GAMEPLAY: Click anywhere on the screen to go to a menu usually I either reserched or devoloped a new game. When you develop a game you pick a topic, pick a genre,( two later on) what console it will be on, the engine, and the name(which doesn't effect the game at all). When you start developing something it'll have these dots( either orange: design, dark orange: bugs, blue: technology, and dark blue: research) they will go to these tabs and these also depend on how good your game is. Also these menus pop up where say you can only have 99 jelly beans. Which Those are divided into 3 parts (3 times for a game) you can only have 99 jelly beans so, say if you want to focus more on graphic than sound then sound could be like 66 jelly beans and the other two are 33. Overall this game is very fun( also there are mods) the first time you beat it you feel acomplished. But the second time you can keep your hints about what goes and what doesn't. 9.5/10

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a game I have played before it came on steam, I was there not long after it came out, and I've stayed their since.

Pros-
Great concept provides replayability
Gives the player lots of choice
Good difficulty level makes bankrupcy sometimes hard to avoid (good as a challenge)
Modable if you ever get bored

Bad-
Everything is an algorithm, one which is easy to figure out
Often you find yourself making the same game over and over, instead of being creative just to do well.

Conclusion-
Overall, it is a great game with a amount of replay value, but can become a rinse and repeat game.
8.5/10

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a fun and entertaining Simulator that allows players to take control of their own Game Company, starting off in the basement on their own, the Simulation tasks players with carefully creating a team of developers to aid them in their game making, while making game history!

Pros:
- Easy to use and read UI
- Takes players through console history up to the present day.
- Helpful tutorial
- Addictive Start-Mid game content
- Active and friendly community, as well as a decently explained wikia page

Cons:
- Less End game content (i.e research, office expansions, staff training)
- Not much replayability, except to beat your previous score, unless you went bankrupt before the end of the game or for the achievements.

Conclusion:
Excellent game, the developers care for the game and community by actively increasing the content and fixing bugs. Definitely worth £6.99
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Have you ever dreamed of being a game developer and designing the perfect game? Well, now you can!

Game Dev Tycoon is a charming business sim where your main aim is to make great games (and rake in cash by doing so). The system is fairly simple: pick a genre and platform, then adjust the sliders as needed to allocate different amounts of time to different aspects of the game, and assigning different people to handle said aspects. However, while the basic development process is simple and easy to grasp, there's a surprising amount of depth to the game. As you progress through the years, new platforms will appear on the market, and you'll be able to unlock new genres of games to make, and new features to put in your custom engines, so that you can customize your games to be just about anything you want them to be. Eventually you'll be able to do massive projects like AAA games, MMOs, and even original consoles. Mods for the game often add even more features, topics, and events, increasing the customizability. All of this makes a really simple but entertaining and addictive game, as you let your imagination run free.

The game has very bare-bones graphics, but it doesn't really need much to work anyway. The main appeal of the game is letting your imagination form its own image of what kind of games you're making, and trying to make them as good and successful as possible. It doesn't have much music either, but what few music tracks it does have are nice enough, Still, it wouldn't have hurt to add a few more songs.

It's not a perfect game, though. While the customization aspect is one of the main draws, it can actually end up a drawback as well, in a couple of ways. First, there are sometimes simply TOO MANY options, and not enough resources to obtain them for use (a problem that can be exacerbated by mods that add even more). See, the way you unlock new genres and engine features, is by researching them by spending research points. You get these by developing games and engines, and by completing contract work, but you don't have any control over how many you get, while new features keep costing more and more as the game goes on (each new genre costs 10 RP... early engine features like mono sound also cost 10-15, but more advanced ones will cost 20, 40, 80, or more, up to 200). You also have to spend research points to upgrade your team's skills, spreading them even more thin. This can often feel imbalanced, and like you never have enough points to upgrade what you want.

There is also, unfortunately, a degree of railroading in the customization as well, because while you can make whatever kind of game you like, there are pre-set combinations listed as successful or otherwise on different platforms. You CAN go and make that Horror Simulation game for Young audiences, but you shouldn't expect it to score or sell as well as a Fantasy RPG, or indeed very well in any case. It would have been nice if the game had let you be a little more innovative and out-of-the-box with your games.

Still, despite these drawbacks, the core of the game is still very solid. It's still loads of fun to make new games. It's fun to try and get new features to add to them. The business end of it, while a little on the light side, is also good. Altogether this makes for a good, if not amazing, simulator that you'll still find yourself sinking plenty of hours into.

As a bonus, it does come with a lot of fun achievements of various levels of difficulty (a lot of which are hidden but can be looked up), and Steam cards, for those who like those kinds of things.

Good luck, and remember: always aim for 11s.

reviewText: 'Game Dev Tycoon' is certainly the best Tycoon game I've ever played. 'Greenheart Games' have done an excellent job with their first title, as I did mine and I look forward to some great entries from them in the future.

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful game for what it represents. The plot is fantastic and I love how it uses true events with slightly renamed consoles and games, far better than if they made up all the consoles and games. The game gives you a lot of choice, is very simple to understand and with so many different possibilities and outcomes, the game has yet to become stale for me so far.

However, in my hour so far of playing, I am already finding it very hard to make perfect games. Whilst game reports are a very good way to get information about good and bad combos, the reviews are lacking in depth with some simply saying things like 'Enjoyed it' and 'Good'. If the reviewers went into more depth like they sometimes do when mentioning things like 'medieval works really well with strategy' then I'd much prefer the reviews and actually find them useful, however, as it stands, the best way to get information on your game is to file a game report.

Whilst I have not played this game for too long, my first impressions are for the most part very positive. The game is very simple to play and is perfect for some relaxing late-night gaming. The game adds enough challenge with its numerous choices and certainly does require a lot of thought into some decisions in order to maintain enough money to save yourself from going bankrupt, however isn't impossibly difficult to grasp.

Overall, my opinion on 'Game Dev Tycoon' is very positive, however I do feel the lack of in-depth reviews really does hinder its potential. But this is one con among many pros and should certainly not put you off playing this wonderfully unique experience.

Rating: 3/4

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a very interesting game. You start alone in garage, and end as boss of big company. There's many reaserch option, and making the game isn't always easy. You have to take risk of letting someone overwork to end the game, and you cannot always have everything you want in the game - choose wisely. There is game reports mechanic that allows you to gain insights about released games (like the x topic is great with x genre or like ai is very important for x genre games).
There are plenty interesting events that makes a game more interesting, but there isn't many of them. You can make your own consoles from scratch as like a engine. There are many options but i feel like some things aren't balanced good, but maybe only  I've got that feeling. The game is also short. Sometimes you don't know what some options are to. For example, why you can don't have/have online play in MMO? MMO is MMO O_O. The stupid thing is that expansion packs to MMO are made exactly like games. So you can have worse graphic in the same game in DLC. Beside that this game is really fun. If you've seen some videos on Youtube from it and you liked it you should get it. Maybe not for full price, but definitely on promotion. Also there are plenty mods that i haven't tried yet, that will probably make the game better.

+: Many reaserch options
Game development leads you to hard choices
Mod support
Nice amount of topics
References to reality like Govodore G64, Playsystem, Übersoft, Vony, Peter Polyneux :D
Ability to make own engine and console
Make your own game dev studio from scratch

-:Small amount of events
Some bugs
Not everything is good balanced
Stupid expansion pack system to MMO's
Not everything is understandable
All Games" hate me and when everybody give me 10 they give me 9
Occasional lag
Slightly short

7+/10
Best of it's kind
Comand94

reviewText:
Have you ever dreamed of being a game developer and designing the perfect game? Well, now you can!

Game Dev Tycoon is a charming business sim where your main aim is to make great games (and rake in cash by doing so). The system is fairly simple: pick a genre and platform, then adjust the sliders as needed to allocate different amounts of time to different aspects of the game, and assigning different people to handle said aspects. However, while the basic development process is simple and easy to grasp, there's a surprising amount of depth to the game. As you progress through the years, new platforms will appear on the market, and you'll be able to unlock new genres of games to make, and new features to put in your custom engines, so that you can customize your games to be just about anything you want them to be. Eventually you'll be able to do massive projects like AAA games, MMOs, and even original consoles. Mods for the game often add even more features, topics, and events, increasing the customizability. All of this makes a really simple but entertaining and addictive game, as you let your imagination run free.

The game has very bare-bones graphics, but it doesn't really need much to work anyway. The main appeal of the game is letting your imagination form its own image of what kind of games you're making, and trying to make them as good and successful as possible. It doesn't have much music either, but what few music tracks it does have are nice enough, Still, it wouldn't have hurt to add a few more songs.

It's not a perfect game, though. While the customization aspect is one of the main draws, it can actually end up a drawback as well, in a couple of ways. First, there are sometimes simply TOO MANY options, and not enough resources to obtain them for use (a problem that can be exacerbated by mods that add even more). See, the way you unlock new genres and engine features, is by researching them by spending research points. You get these by developing games and engines, and by completing contract work, but you don't have any control over how many you get, while new features keep costing more and more as the game goes on (each new genre costs 10 RP... early engine features like mono sound also cost 10-15, but more advanced ones will cost 20, 40, 80, or more, up to 200). You also have to spend research points to upgrade your team's skills, spreading them even more thin. This can often feel imbalanced, and like you never have enough points to upgrade what you want.

There is also, unfortunately, a degree of railroading in the customization as well, because while you can make whatever kind of game you like, there are pre-set combinations listed as successful or otherwise on different platforms. You CAN go and make that Horror Simulation game for Young audiences, but you shouldn't expect it to score or sell as well as a Fantasy RPG, or indeed very well in any case. It would have been nice if the game had let you be a little more innovative and out-of-the-box with your games.

Still, despite these drawbacks, the core of the game is still very solid. It's still loads of fun to make new games. It's fun to try and get new features to add to them. The business end of it, while a little on the light side, is also good. Altogether this makes for a good, if not amazing, simulator that you'll still find yourself sinking plenty of hours into.

As a bonus, it does come with a lot of fun achievements of various levels of difficulty (a lot of which are hidden but can be looked up), and Steam cards, for those who like those kinds of things.

Good luck, and remember: always aim for 11s.

reviewText:
Love it.

This is pretty much a no brainer, for any tycoon fan at least.

Despite not being extremely important, the graphics are really nice, and don't get boring to look at (which, let's face it, you'll spend a lot of time looking at it), and are followed by a regular soundtrack. The gameplay is incredibly good, allowing you to train your character, and hire a couple more (and train them, too). You'll also be able to upgrade your office once you've earned (milked) enough money from your fans, and you'll also be able to research new technologies and such throughout the years.

Eventually, you'll even be able to start your own ♥♥♥♥♥♥mes, and that's when the real milking begins. Or it should. That's probably the one thing I feel it's a bit off with GDT. The MMO system is bad, in my opinion. And, since I'm not really into modding, I've never really tried any of the mods available, which are many. But I've read, and heard from friends, that there are some really really good mods.

I've actually spent more hours playing this than steam actually states, for some reason, so, that's something to take into consideration, too.

I'd recommend this game any day of the year.

reviewText:
Ah, Game Dev Tycoon. I find this game fantastic, for one core reason. It's brilliant wishfulness which lets players build and grow a gaming company. You will hire employees, purchase buildings, develop games, build consoles and anything else you can imagine. This is where the game shines, it allows people to an extent express how they think a game company should be ran.

However while most gamers will enjoy this game to some degree, if you don't find the idea of running your own company appealing, you'll likely find the game fairly boring since the gameplay is fairly basic. With it completely based upon moving sliders which represent how you and your employees focus effort on how you build your games.


Pros:
Thematic
Endless Wishfulness for gamers
Steam workshop helps the longevity of play

Cons:
Gameplay is fairly simple and can get fairly boring
Game is fairly unclear on how to make quality games
Won't get much out if it, if you don't care for the consent of running your own game company.

Linux port report: I found the Linux version of this game to be adequate, it still runs smoother on windows, but it's a good effort none the less. The only problems I found was a little bit of additional delay when selecting menus and an occasional font sizing problem. However, despite this, it is perfectly playable on Linux.

Overall it's a Solid Recommendation

reviewText: It's a trial-and-error-based strategy game, and once you start to figure out each of the five genres, the game is pretty easy. Even with multi-genre mixups it's pretty self-explanatory on how to allocate your time during development. Past this thin surface level of gameplay, there really isn't enough depth to keep you going.\n\nA lot of seemingly obvious features are missing from the development process, probably to keep the game simpler and more accessible, but I feel like a lot of replayability is lost in their absence. For every step in the development process of a game, I found myself wanting more concise control, but this is by no means a game of micro-management. You market your game by pressing market" and have little to no input on HOW your game is marketed
date: for example. The success of your game winds up relying on when you release your game
recommended: and how you allocated your time. It's so bare-bones and minimal that the sense of achievement wears off quickly and you begin to feel like you're not working for your success.\n\nThat being said
hoursPlayed: I still played for about 10-12 hours before it was effortles and mundane
voteText: so I think I still got my moneys worth. If you're looking for a simple game to relax to where you don't have to do much aside from click through menu's
helpfulPercent: it's a great choice
votesHelpful: and that's really all I wanted."

reviewText:
His game is a wonderful nostalgia trip, with some minor flaws.

The graphic is nice and a little reto the music gets a bit annoying after a while.

Gamplay is solid, with some minor issues.
The game roughly separates in three phases: Garage, small time developer and AAA-Studio.

The first phase is easy and was my personal favourite: You just make games you like and combine new ideas, without any boring micro management.

The second phase steps up the difficulty a notch: You move into a studio and hire staff to make even bigger games.
Suddendly you have to maage much more stuff and cash becomes a serious issue.
Do you burn money on a new game-engine or concentrate on churning out games.

The third and final stage is a bit easier in my opinion: You hire more guys and concentrate on AAA-Titels, enlarge your studio and develop stuff like steam, you own consol and convention and so on...

My complaints are that after the time seems to fly by" at phase 2 and 3. Consols come and go and you almost have no chance to develop anything for them so you stay at one system you know well (the PC) and stick with it.

You have to train your avatar and staff using reseach points
date:
which are not to easy to get in abundance.
When you have enough research points and a trained staff at the final phase the game is almost over.

Some of the user interface is also no designed perfectly
recommended: but that may be my personal taste.\n\nAll in all a fun little experience with potential."

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a wonderful game for what it represents. The plot is fantastic and I love how it uses true events with slightly renamed consoles and games, far better than if they made up all the consoles and games. The game gives you a lot of choice, is very simple to understand and with so many different possibilities and outcomes, the game has yet to become stale for me so far.

However, in my hour so far of playing, I am already finding it very hard to make perfect games. Whilst game reports are a very good way to get information about good and bad combos, the reviews are lacking in depth with some simply saying things like 'Enjoyed it' and 'Good'. If the reviewers went into more depth like they sometimes do when mentioning things like 'medieval works really well with strategy' then I'd much prefer the reviews and actually find them useful, however, as it stands, the best way to get information on your game is to file a game report.

Whilst I have not played this game for too long, my first impressions are for the most part very positive. The game is very simple to play and is perfect for some relaxing late-night gaming. The game adds enough challenge with its numerous choices and certainly does require a lot of thought into some decisions in order to maintain enough money to save yourself from going bankrupt, however isn't impossibly difficult to grasp.

Overall, my opinion on 'Game Dev Tycoon' is very positive, however I do feel the lack of in-depth reviews really does hinder its potential. But this is one con among many pros and should certainly not put you off playing this wonderfully unique experience.

Rating: 3/4

reviewText:
This game is AWESOME!
Honestly, any game where you can create best-selling games which have names like 'Drop That Soap' and make advanced consoles called the 'Compubox Too' is one worth investing in. There are so many great mods in this game, but I have not invested in these too much yet.
I recently played through the game in a 6/7-hour game and actually discovered several features which I had not previously discovered (such as the homage to this service which is dubbed 'Grid') and, not only was it fun to play, but the experience was different; and no two files will likely have the same development path for topics, as all of the topics appear in a random order.
This game is one of my personal favourites, not only for the hilarious titles that can come up, but for the achievements which bay homage to classic games (such as Pong and Doom). I would recommend this to any casual gamer who is happy to spend countless hours playing this legendary game.

10/10

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a fun little casual game well worth picking up while on sale. You start as a single person in your garage and work your way up to the CEO of an AAA game studio. Anyone who has played a variety of games over the years will enjoy coming up with their favorite game combos and thinking from the end of an indie game developer. I think the style of the artwork may convey a generic-ville type feeling but it's a proper game. There is no in-game purchasing micro-transaction garbage. The game has a definite goal and is not a mindless grinding simulator. I am a slow gamer but it took me about thirty hours before I was able to complete all the achievements in the game. I will likely put another ten hours in just to see how fast I can beat the game now that I have proper experience in it.

I think some of the negative reviews that are on here are frustrated with replay value and min/maxing their games. I'd like to address that.

This game is most fun when experienced at the beginning without a guide. If you go in with a guide you're just going to want to hit all the hard points right off the bat and you'll completely lose the fun the game, even if you succeed. Don't be afraid to try things and learn, as the game is very good with rewarding you regardless of success or failure. For example if you decide to try a game combination/configuration that does not work, the game permanently records a reminder in your history when you write your game report. Should you decide to restart your game, it will give you the option to retain that knowledge in the new game. Game Dev Tycoon is also good about not giving you too much to handle up front, easing you into the development process, while at the same time not giving you any choices that are completely useless. So feel free to experiment with new opportunities! When it is beneficial for you to use a publisher the option will appear (never too soon.) and even the random 'events' that occur give you a bonus even if you make the 'wrong choice'.

When it comes to replay again I believe it relies on not getting a game guide right off the bat. You'll go bankrupt a few times learning but it's okay, like I mentioned your 'progress' is still pretty much saved. Once you get the swing of things you'll quickly level your studio up quickly to where you were previously. With a guide you'll just be frustrated you are not hitting 10/10 games every single time and just quit at the beginning.

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a fun little casual game well worth picking up while on sale. You start as a single person in your garage and work your way up to the CEO of an AAA game studio. Anyone who has played a variety of games over the years will enjoy coming up with their favorite game combos and thinking from the end of an indie game developer. I think the style of the artwork may convey a generic-ville type feeling but it's a proper game. There is no in-game purchasing micro-transaction garbage. The game has a definite goal and is not a mindless grinding simulator. I am a slow gamer but it took me about thirty hours before I was able to complete all the achievements in the game. I will likely put another ten hours in just to see how fast I can beat the game now that I have proper experience in it.

I think some of the negative reviews that are on here are frustrated with replay value and min/maxing their games. I'd like to address that.

This game is most fun when experienced at the beginning without a guide. If you go in with a guide you're just going to want to hit all the hard points right off the bat and you'll completely lose the fun the game, even if you succeed. Don't be afraid to try things and learn, as the game is very good with rewarding you regardless of success or failure. For example if you decide to try a game combination/configuration that does not work, the game permanently records a reminder in your history when you write your game report. Should you decide to restart your game, it will give you the option to retain that knowledge in the new game. Game Dev Tycoon is also good about not giving you too much to handle up front, easing you into the development process, while at the same time not giving you any choices that are completely useless. So feel free to experiment with new opportunities! When it is beneficial for you to use a publisher the option will appear (never too soon.) and even the random 'events' that occur give you a bonus even if you make the 'wrong choice'.

When it comes to replay again I believe it relies on not getting a game guide right off the bat. You'll go bankrupt a few times learning but it's okay, like I mentioned your 'progress' is still pretty much saved. Once you get the swing of things you'll quickly level your studio up quickly to where you were previously. With a guide you'll just be frustrated you are not hitting 10/10 games every single time and just quit at the beginning.

reviewText:
I reviewed this game quite a while ago after I played it through till the end when I first bought it a couple of years ago, I recommended it and praised it as a good game. After playing Game Dev Tycoon  through again for a while to get some of the last achievements (Finally managed 100%) I still think it's a good title, but I'm not entirely sure how much fun it actually is after a certain amount of time.

Tycoon games are always hit and miss, this one is probably one of the best I have played, it is very adictive and simply fun to play, tons of combinations making for many possible results make acheiveing your goals somewhat of a challenge at times, unless you discover a formula that happens to work for you constantly. I'd say one of the best features about the game is how it takes you back to the 80's and runs through the timeline of real game development, showing how different consoles by different companies effected the market and sales of games in reality, a really nice trip down memory lane.

There are a good amount of achievements to acquire if you like to push yourself the extra mile like me, some of which can be really difficult to acquire such as Unobtainium and the 11/10 achievements, this gives the game some replayability and is one of the reasons I re-installed and played it through again. The games technical aspects go much deeper than you'd expect just by looking at it which I'd say is a good thing and makes the game less predictable, you'll certainly understand that if you go achievement hunting.
After a while however, the game stopped being fun and felt more like a grinding chore rather than actually playing a game. It's not a bad game by any means, I just feel it can lose it's charm after a while, as is normally the case with some forumlaic games.

With all that being said, Game Dev Tycoon is still probably the best management / tycoon game I have played and definitely recommend buying it if you're into that sort of thing, or maybe even if you're looking to get into the genre I'd say it's a good spring-board for it. For it's low price, you will get a fair amount of gameplay out of it and for the most part it can be good fun.

reviewText:
Alright so to be fair, I only played this game for about a day so later game content may or may not make a bigger impact on the game. Also, there seems to be a pretty active mod scene but I didn't go into that.

The concept is a simple simulation or Tycoon type game where you play as a one man indie game developer who slowly grows his/her company into a major game developer woth tens of millions of dollars.

This is done through a really simple interface. You just pick the topic and type of game you're making and then allocate resources to various aspects of game development such as artificial intelligence or level design. This gains more nuances as you advance in the game but game development remains the same simple core mechanic for the whole experience. There's also other things you can do to benefit your company such as contract work, marketing, etc. There are also random events that can hurt or benefit you depending on how you respond to them a la FTL.

It's a fun experience overall if you enjoy these sorts of business simulation games. It also strikes a special chord with a lot of gamers who can take the opportunity to name their games after popular franchises or just push stupid crap onto the gaming audience.

I do have a few gripes though. Although the game does retain some information on how certain games should ideally be made the game doesn't really tell you a whole lot. There were several times where I thought I was following the instructions on how to make a successfull game but it flopped and I had no idea why even after doing a game report. Also, I think it's unfair that certain topic/genre combinations can't be successful if handled properly. I personally think my Werewolf RTS game would be great. Also, I think it's unrealistic that 1. People in this universe seem to follow game reviews very closely and 2. It's not possible to have a huge success with a bad game, that ♥♥♥♥ happens in real life all the time.

However, although I might pick it up again eventually, especially to try out some mods. My biggest problem with the game was that it got very boring after a day of play. Overall though, it's a strong recommendation for anyone who's a fan of old school Tycoon games.
voteText: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
For $10.99 this game proves to be worth the money. Made only by 2 people Game Dev Tycoon proves to be a very positive start to Greenheart Games, providing smooth and addictive gameplay.

Gameplay: Simple to grasp and very diverse it offers a good in depth look at the game industry and allows you to make repetitive COD games and watch them flop as they should. Gameplay is heavily addictive and makes you want to keep playing until you make that big block buster game and then keeps you striving to best that one. I have nearly 10 hours in just two days which is a rather high amount.

Pros:

-Game has workshop support and there's lots of mods on the shop I can't say if they're good because I'm too busy with the base game to get into the mods atm but I'll update this review later. *UPDATE* so ive broswed the steam workshop for this game and there is a fair amount of mods that add some nice content to the game. That being said the workshop support definetly adds to the games worth.

-Very easy to get the hang of.

- Has real life consoles (renamed to avoid copy right) and has some real game industry history behind them like the PS2 putting Sega out of business or the Sony VS Microsoft feud.

- Allows you to make mobile and handheld/portable games (I.E. Apple Phone,Nintendo DS,PSP. ETC)

- You can make your own console to compete with other developers and then make games exclusivly for your console.

-Can take part in industrail sabatage.

-Real life hazards. (I.E. Credit Card Fraud, Games not living up to hype resulting in poor sales, People pirating your games. ETC)

- Played for 10 hours and havent incountered any bugs or glitches which is a big PRO.

- Very diverse and has a lot of depth and really provides some cool insight into the game industry.


Neutral:

- Can feel like good ratings are luck based at times but in the real game industry thats sometimes the case so not a negative or positive.

- It can feel like a bit of a grind to increase the stats of your employees (I.E. increasing Tech, Design, Speed)

- You Can't set the price of your games. Games sell at fixed rates which doesnt ruin gameplay but takes away from the immersion a little.

CONS:

-Game can eventually feel repetitive.

- Not a lot of generes (I.E. When making a game you can pick from only a few generes that are popular ones but none the less you have limited selection and no way of unlocking more (you can unlock the casual games but thats the only one to my knowledge) ***Will update if I find a way outside the workshop to get more***

- *** No more cons that I can think of currently for game dev tycoon. If I find some I will post them here.


Rating: 9.5/10

Explanation for Rating: Game Dev Tycoon for its low price of $10.99 (CAD) offers solid gameplay and gives you your moneys worth. For a game made by two people it sure was well developed and thought out. The game has no major bugs or glitches that I have encountered yet. Greenheart games have given it Steam Workshop support which more game devs should follow suit in as its an easy way to allow fans of the game to continue to add to the game by making mods which double as free DLC. If the game had the things I mentioned in the neutral section and found a way to maybe fix the cons this would easily be a 10/10 but for their first game a 9.5 is solid better than what I did in Game Dev Tycoon I got a meazly 5.25.

reviewText:
You start off as a single game dev operating out of your garage, and then slowly expand as you move to bigger office, hire more people and just grow.

The game starts off in the distant past, and contains homages to major consoles & other gaming device, albeit with similar names, no doubt to avoid legal wrangles.

Gameplay wise, this game will have you hooked. From researching new topics to new technologies for your custom game engine to training yourself & staff to generating reports on your past games to figuring out what game/topic/genre/system combo works well to delivering that blockbuster game - you'll be doing all these tasks at once, but with none of the micromanagement.

Sounds are nice, but it is the gameplay which will have you on playing for a while - trying to squeeze that one game with hopes that it will get a perfect score.

Highly recommended.

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is one of those surprises that you find along your game year. I was waiting until Steam Sale to purchase this game, due to lack of reviews/people talking about it. You see, I'm a big fan of Tycoon games, and its easy to play one of this genre and see a lot of mistakes/bugs ruining the gameplay. This is not true to GDT. If I knew what I know now, I'd purchase this game right away.

Combining a good mixture of good design and gameplay, Greenheart Games made me feel like the little guy in the garage building my first game. You see, with Tycoon games you usually see yourself as the manager or some kind of God Like creature. In this title I felt so compelled to strive that I couldn't wait to release my major game and everytime a so-so review came in, I felt dissapointed.

The pacing is great. Along the years you see consoles rise and fall and new technologies appear. Eventually you move out of your little garage and a office takes place. Then a fellow co-worker or two...And when you realize, its been 20 years already and you're a multi-million game dev studio, with lots of employees and each one with a different skill.

Although the interface is not winning Design award of the Year, it's still very user friendly, and will leave no room for doubt as to where things are and how they work.

This game takes me back to the time where I found a sentiment of wonder" in games. Greenheart Games
