reviewText:
When purchasing this game, little did I know how addicting it would be. I've played a similar game on my iPhone, but this one is by far more challenging and has more to offer.

You start off in your garage, on your own, making video games. As you progress you move up into your own office and can hire people to work for you. Each game you make you choose the amount of time and effort that is put into producing certain aspects of the game. You also can research more enhancements that can be used to create your own gaming engine to produce even better games. Once a game is made and released it gets rated by four gaming magazines (those jerks can be a bit harsh at times...And yes, giving your game a name does seem to matter because if you don't one of thse guys ussually calls you on it).

This game has replay value to it, which is what I enjoy. You can go back, make a new company and try and outdo yourself, try different combinations, do what ever you want. Good game, and I would suggest giving it a try.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText: A lot of people seem to think that developing games is as easy as doing what you did the last time, but only doing it better. The gaming industry can be very finicky, and usually successful games are successful if the market and timing is just right. But to anyone that thinks that they can make video games, here ya go. Starting you off at the beginning of the video game revolution, but just after the Video Game Crash of '83, this game puts you in the role of a software designer. I use that term over video game maker because you can develop game engines, pick up white hat hacking jobs from different companies for cash and develop games for a variety of consoles. I got as far as the Playstation/N64 era with my games, and saw the release of the Dreamcast, but I failed due to poor decisions, rehashes, and bad marketing. It's not that the game is tough, you should just know that you can't expect a great game just because of a name, which is true to real life. I highly recommend this game, not only because of how real it felt, but also because of how much fun it is. If you've ever wondered if you could make video games for a living, believe me, this game is for you.

reviewText:
I bought this game because it looked like something I hadn't played before, and I was so right, it reminded me of some other games, but this is much more addicting and fun.

I started playing the second I bought it, and everything was super simple to understand and figure out. In the beginning you startup like almost every Indie-developer, in your own house(in this case a garage). You have a relative small budget to start off with, and few variations on which platform to publish your games, but the thing is that every single thing in this game evolve with time.
The first time you play it, you only have a few good selling games, and when I say a few, I mean like 1-5 max. But when the world understands what great games are, then you just have to figure out know when they are ready for different genres and specific platforms.

After the first time I opened the game, I played for 6 straight hours nonstop. I had so much fun, and every single detail in the game made sense and I was nervous for every single review.

If you ever feel bored, and want to try something new, buy this game, you won't regret it... it's way too much fun.

reviewText:
There is a good solid 4-6 hours in this game (just one play through), especially if you can make it to the end of the game, and make the correct decisions.

The Good:
- You have to make the right decisions to make the most successful game.  There isn't a lot of randomness to your game ratings. You really do feel like you are in control.
- It is fun to see the history of the gaming industry over the last 20 years or so, and relive some of your childhood by actually developing for some of your favorite consoles!

The Bad:
- Each time you play through the game, the same consoles and events in history happen.  It would be nice to have alternate timelines where some consoles did bad that would normally do good.
- After you figure out what combos work the best, and the mechanics, there really isn't much challenge to the game.

Overall, I do recommend this game, but make sure you get it on sale!

reviewText: We don't get very many of these, I do want one, a good one that will make me feel like an actual dev, Game Dev Tycoon is nothing short of mediocre. The game does well in some aspects such as money management, giving you wild genres to have fun with, and is suprisingly a lot of fun because it lets you make games with awful titles and doesn't care. I would love to see an actual in depth game like this, but Game Dev Tycoon fails on major issues like actually giving you feedback on the games you develop.  It's basically a hit and miss with games you make, sometimes you can make what you feel is a really good game, yet get awful scores and no reason on why it was terrible, giving you no way to improve on your skills. Then the game doesn't go into depth in the right places like what you're putting your work into during the dev stage, is design going into the style of the tracks, or is it going to the whole overall game including the scenery, people cheering and such. I like the game, it's fun, worth the four dollars it was on sale for (even though it was gifted to me), it has nice music, it gets a bit boring after awhile but still nice, and sort of gives you the basic feel of being a dev, I went backrupt a lot but that was mostly because I didn't have any idea on how to improve my games. 6/10, get it maybe during the Holiday Sale if you can.

reviewText:
My first thoughts about this game were contradictory - Creating games while playing game? But I've decided to give It a try especially since It showed up on sale. I was wrong, Game Dev Tycoon brings you decent fun for a few hours, depending on your end game goal. I've found this game quite challenging from start, since you can get easily bankrupted for making a series of bad decisions while learning game mechanics, but that's what It's about, right?

I had a great time watching how my company grows, but after you reach top scores and end-game, It gets very repetitive.
Maybe if there was more game mechanics (ingame ones are simple and game Itself limits you in styles how you create and sell your products).

Overall I didn't regret buying this game on sale, but I would if I paid full price.

reviewText:
Start up your own games studio in a garage.

The developers have clearly stated that Game Dev Story was one of their inspirations, so if you know or have played that game, then Game Dev Tycoon is pretty much that plus a lot more.

You start as an independent developer in a garage, and step by step you work your way up through the industry creating and releasing various games. One could say, well, okay, that sounds extremely boring, but trust me - it's addictive and you really get that feeling of satisfaction watching the numbers grow.

After about 20 hours, you already get the basic idea about how the game works and how to get more and more cash easily and it all gets repetitive and boring, so keep that in mind when purchasing - but I would say it is worth it, even if only for those 20 hours.

reviewText: Game Dev Tycoon is exactly what you expect: a videogame developer tycoon. You are supposedly warped back in time to 1985 to a reference-filled (hint: flux capacitor) garage, where you begin your endeavour into the gaming history books. Like any developer who travels in time to 1985, you are absolute ♥♥♥♥ at programming because the technology is so different.  You have a computer that's literally worse than a modern graphing calculator, yet you decide to make games. If you are successful, you can grow your garage into an actual company, with actual people, and actual results. You have to strategically market your games for specific audiences (you know, like T for Teen" or "E for Everyone") and try to match genres to different gaming platforms to different audiences.\n\nFor example

reviewText: I bought this in the holiday sale for practically peanuts. I got hooked straight away and realised I got myself more then a bargain! I advise you to start a game and learn the basics. You will more than likely go bankrupt quite early on but you will be much better prepared for your second attempt. I failed again at my second attempt so then got the cheat mod to just stop me from going bankrupt. On my third playthrough I reinvented SEGA and made them into the number one game/console development company. Theres a lot of fun in recreating your favourite games and turning them into AAA 10/10 titles. So far it has been 16 hours very well spent. The reviews I read here made me buy this game, You wont regret doing the same thing!

reviewText:
Great game overall, well worth the $2 I paid it for it when it was on sale a while ago

I rarely write reviews but this game is actually really fun to play and considering it came from an indie developer I'm very impressed.

Here's a list of pros and cons.

Pros

Simple and easy to understand (tool tips pop up and explain most things, basic 'help' section also)
Multiple consoles to develop for (pretty much all of them, missing a few smaller ones but still great)
Lots of topics and genres to build for
Progress from small slummy garage to sexy building
Towards the end there is lots of do and research (the R&D towards the end is done very well)
Some similarities to other dev games, but really becomes very unique towards the middle to the end (you can specialise your workers etc)
Lots of other cool stuff along the way
Cons (Not really negatives, just small things that could be improved)
Time passes really quickly, would have been good if there was a speed slider, or if it took a little longer for the weeks to pass
Your workers are skilled in development / technology but it seems to me that only 'graphics' is the only skill that utilises the technology attribute (Maybe I just don't quite understand who to assign to different tasks on medium / large games)
Sometimes its hard to see what will be successful by combining topics and genres (it does tell you it may be a good combination after you selected what you want, given you have researched it, however it would be good if you didn't have to go back and forth to select and reselect things
Lots of trial and error in discovering what works, would be good to actually research into a topic to see if the market will like it
Overall great game!

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon was game that as soon as I laid eyes on, I would want to purchase immediately! And well, for the most part, it is that type of material! It's fairly short, but it's fun and engaging, also quite challenging sometimes!

I've always love gaming - and it's apart of my life. Let's face it, I'm a gamer. Yet, I've always tried to make/develop little games to play (Using Unity 3D) and I wasn't too succesful, so I'm more of an enthusiast.

Be that as it may, Game Dev Tycoon allowed to use my mind, and my senses to create games that would sell as if they would in real life. Now, sometimes the combinations of the topics and genres would somehow be not as successful if they were in real life (Ex: Evolution/Casual = Spore) Yet, it all made sense in the end...I guess :/

Overall, it's such a short game there is not too much to review about, but I can easily produce a solid review from playing this game over-and-over.

9/10 - IF you are interested in owning a company and love video games!

reviewText:
This game is fantastic and to prevent myself from going on and on ill just list pros and cons.
Pros:
+LIVE THE DREAM!
+Great amount of content as far as custimizing your games engine and graphics and features
+Enjoyably difficult in the early years (i found myself almost going bankrupt on four occasions during my rise to fame only to be saved by a single game that saved my company)
+Humorus satire
+Devlop your own console and decide specs
+Great modding community

Cons:
-Player custimization is limited
-Console appearence design is limited to just a few presets
-Lack of a few key topics (shooters and beat-em ups are missing among others)
-Lack of any kind of graphs or information on competitors and bestsellers.

All in all 9/10 Perfect bargain, well worth the price

Side note-I believe the addition of being able to sign with a company and make exclusives would enhance the already great depth of this game also to be able to bankrupt other companies and take them over. Competing would be nice as well with a rivial(Dice v.s Whoever is making the years installment of COD). Also id like to see more depth, an example could be instead of just a sport game you could list a specific sport like football. Instead of just military how about sub catagories like ww2 and stuff.

reviewText:
A lot of the reviews for Game Dev Tycoon criticize it for being a blatant rip-off of a popular game on mobile devices - having played both I agree that the game is almost entirely unoriginal.  Does it matter?  I don't think so, should no one else be allowed to make a city simulator because Maxis made SimCity first?  The fact is this game is a lot of fun.

PROS:
-Good graphics.  Really pretty.  Not going to max out your gpu, but the cartooney style looks nice
-Sound.  Its hard to explain but the music and all the little sound effects are really pleasant.  It'll keep you from getting fatigued.
-Re-playability.  You might put in say 10 or 20 hours and feel like you have done it all, but like other sims you should be able to come back at a later date and have lots of fun all over again.

CONS:
-Some of the genre/topics don't work when they should.  Like Werewolf and RPG is a terrible combo - Why?  Ever heard of Wolf Among Us?"
-The game isn't very random
date: you could basically play THE EXACT same strategy and turn of events each play through and have the same outcome\n-The whole game is based on your title's scores.  The scores are based upon your previous scores.  I really don't like this
recommended: by the end of the game it becomes harder and harder to get titles earning 10/10 marks.  In other words
hoursPlayed: to get a second 10/10 game it has to be better than the previous 10/10 game.\n\nOverall - this game is really fun and I definitely recommend it to sim fans of any type."

reviewText:
Tagging Game Dev Tycoon with the labels 'Simulation', 'Indie' and 'Management' may be accurate.  After all, it is a simulation of managing a game development studio (and a surprisingly engaging one).  But, in reality, these tags don't fully do the game justice.

Like great strategy games, it places a premium on decision making without being punishingly constricting.  It has a vein of self-determination that good RPGs possess (i.e. want to become a megalithic AAA pumping machine, or see how far you can go working alone in your garage?).  It allows for flexible resource management like a good business sim should.  But, most importantly,  this is a game that possesses that just-one-more-turn factor that any good game of its ilk needs.  In this case a turn is really a development cycle, but why quibble?

If someone isn't a particular fan of job/business simulators this game still has enough going for it that they're likley to find something to enjoy about it.  At full price the game definitely delivers value for money for fans of the genre.  For others, give it a shot when it's on sale and you likely won't regret it.

reviewText:
This is one of my FAVORITE business sim games. This isn't perfect, but for a first outing from this studio, they did a phenominal job.

Pros:
Rewarding entrepreneurship sim. It feels great to hire the right people and see your products get great reviews year after year. In some very important ways, this is the best entrepreneurship simulator on the market.

It's challenging. I got cocky and without realizing it began bankrupting my first company. The second time around I hired more slowly and trained my people and kept a constant reserve of chash to keep my boat afloat but there were still times when my account would go from being millions of dollars in the black to being more than 100k in the red.

They do a good job of rewarding ethical opperators. Your fans will thank you for making a product with them in mind and not being like some of the more infamous large studios in the real world. (not to mention any names *Cough* EA *Cough*)

Cons:
The years are too short and the time between consol generations are inconsistant. I would like to see this game take a solid 25 or more real world hours to go through the 35 in game years.

The art is inconsistent (look at the art for the game sphere vs the playsystem) I would love to see them come out with a longer, more polished and balanced sequel. I know I'll support it.

reviewText:
Yep.I've played enough to make a review
Let's start.
Game Dev Tycoon is a game about developing games(like the title implies);
You start in a garage with only guy,and then climb all the way up to the top.
There isn't much to say about the game....so let's the positive and negative points of the game
Positive
-You can unselash your imagination while making the titles;
-There are a plenty of combinations;
-There are nice easter eggs and parodies;
-The interface is simple and works well;
Negative
-Lack some content(DLC for normal games,more consoles)
-Unlogical details(per example:you do everyone fantasy rpg and the suddenly turns it into a adventure like game for mature audience in the next sequel/in what world super famicom is average with rpg and casual titles?)
-Lack of soundtrack
Sorry if i mispelled something.....and......i hope this review helped you!
Final Score
85/100

reviewText: The game is pretty simple. You choose a game topic and a corresponding genre for it which you think results in a good combination. Next, you try to find out what areas to prioritize in game development that goes well with your chosen topic ang genre. Don't try to look at cheat sheets! Slowly master a topic/genre combination by making sequels. That is really what the game is about. Not a lot of replayability though as once you finish the campaign, the only thing that you may want to get are the achievements. Definitely pick it up when it's on sale and when you don't mind playing a short game.

reviewText: A new interesting type of game that we haven't seen much of before. It brings you back to the days when gaming was just a baby and lets you play as a game developer. You can make any type of game, from a Call of Duty type Military Action game to a Skyrim type Medieval RPG. You can create small games and big AAA titles. You start by working as a newbie in your garage, to owning a big office with other developers. You choose what element(s) to focus your game development on, and if you focus on the right things for the right game you will end up with a 10/10 game. Heck, you can even get 11/10 if your game is that good.\nCreate your own game engine and research new topics and engine parts.\nAmazing game 9/10.

reviewText: The message of this game is money does not always lead to making a good game. I think the developer shows this message in and out of the game itself. reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon is a game I bought prior to its release on Steam, as such, I got a Key to redeem the game in, do I regret buying this game much earlier than when it came out? ♥♥♥♥ no, Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games where you don't do a whole lot, but the humour of it stems from your imagination, sure you don't see the actual finished game, that'd be far too ambitious, however, what you can do, is utterly hilarious, want to build a Zombie Dancing Game that's also an RPG? Go ahead! What about a School Adventure game for the expy of the PS4? Sure! You can do that! Hell, even naming these games is humourus on its own, such as a hit from my pre-steam version of the Game: Mary Teaches Sleeping, which got 10s across the board.

When you've played long enough, you can create a custom console, which, in all sakes and purposes, practically becomes a Steam Machine, in which you'd want everything on your own console and PC only, as that generates profit, either that, or you can create MMOs, which are costly as all hell, but if you can maintain enough balance to keep them running, you'll be a Trilionaire

And Acheievements? There are a ton of references to Gaming Culture in here, like making a game that includes Red Barrels, or taking up an offer from a Cave Johnson Expy, or even the silly achievements like Take too long coming up with a name for your game" or something along those lines.

To put it simply
date: Game Dev Tycoon is one of those games that unleashes your creativity

reviewText:
I ummm and arrred before buying this game, it was on sale. But would it be worth the $5.99 I going to pay for it. Probably not.

Well 7.2 Hours later I got my monies worth.

For those of us dreamed of owning our own gaming companies and producing quality titles, with out the BS of the industry and marketing people directing our games. Is this a little peek under the sheets, hell NO. It is an accounting simualtion with a little bit of bar twisting trying to find the right ingredients to make the largest profit.

Yes the developers spice it with a little bit of story and gaming history, but much of your enjoyment is in your imigination. That why 7.2 hours later I am going to bed. It not very hard on the thinking department but it has just enough of everything to give it, 7.5 spanking monkeys out of 10. Enough to get an erection but not enough to j izz my pants.

For the rest of the  90% population, the OCD squeekers, this is not a game for you. You get maybe three hours before you need to jump online and troll someone.

reviewText:
Great game overall, well worth the $2 I paid it for it when it was on sale a while ago

I rarely write reviews but this game is actually really fun to play and considering it came from an indie developer I'm very impressed.

Here's a list of pros and cons.

Pros

Simple and easy to understand (tool tips pop up and explain most things, basic 'help' section also)
Multiple consoles to develop for (pretty much all of them, missing a few smaller ones but still great)
Lots of topics and genres to build for
Progress from small slummy garage to sexy building
Towards the end there is lots of do and research (the R&D towards the end is done very well)
Some similarities to other dev games, but really becomes very unique towards the middle to the end (you can specialise your workers etc)
Lots of other cool stuff along the way
Cons (Not really negatives, just small things that could be improved)
Time passes really quickly, would have been good if there was a speed slider, or if it took a little longer for the weeks to pass
Your workers are skilled in development / technology but it seems to me that only 'graphics' is the only skill that utilises the technology attribute (Maybe I just don't quite understand who to assign to different tasks on medium / large games)
Sometimes its hard to see what will be successful by combining topics and genres (it does tell you it may be a good combination after you selected what you want, given you have researched it, however it would be good if you didn't have to go back and forth to select and reselect things
Lots of trial and error in discovering what works, would be good to actually research into a topic to see if the market will like it
Overall great game!

reviewText:
This is a fantastic game that'll keep you coming back for more as you try to prove yourself in the competetive Game Industry and bring your company to fame and fortune.

It starts you off with the simple premise that you are a fledgling Game Developer trying to make a name for yourself in the still infantile Gaming World back in the 1980s. From there on out you have to use your limited budget to try and develop games, grow your fanbase, and hopefully move your company out of your parents garage.

The gameplay is rather simple and user-friendly which is fantastic for the beginning player but can get a tad tedious once you're on your 7th or 8th run through of the game, that's not to say it makes the game less enjoyable but it would have definitely been a plus if the game let you get a little more hands-on at points. As the game progresses you get to choose which consoles you want to purchase a developing license for, as well as create new game engines as new technology becomes available to you. Careful portioning of your budget is vital to gameplay and a rash spender will soon find themselves bankrupt and bought out.

The game is incredibly simple but has a fun, addictive quality that certainly kept me playing for a good long while and I'm sure that most of you will enjoy as well!

reviewText:
Não tem gráficos excelentes, não tem cutscenes nem jogabilidade dignas de registo. É um Tycoon simples. Mas... tão bem estruturado. É uma espécie de história da indústria dos videojogos, desde as primeiras máquinas às consolas e PCs topos de gama da actualidade.

O tipo de jogos a desenvolver, a sua temática, o motor de jogo, o tipo de som, história, inteligência artificial, etc, etc... todos os pequenos pormenores acabam por entrar, de uma maneira ou de outra, no jogo. E, claro, há tipos de jogos que combinam com determinado tema e outros que funcionam de forma desastrosa. Não se faz um simulador de música, nem um RPG de corridas de carros. Há que acertar na escolha dos jogos a desenvolver e depois no tempo atribuído às diversas fases do seu desenvolvimento. Envolvente, e interessante, capaz de nos manter agarrados a jogar durante bastante tempo.

É um excelente jogo casual, que surpreende pela positiva e entretém durante horas.

This Game is a Amazing Simulation about making video games! reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon. A simple, yet great game. Let me get started.
Firstly, this game is amazing because:
You can mae your own games, your own consoles, complete contracts, work with publishers, make genre/topic combinations, and more. You can also make a Military/Action game, call it Call of Duty with medium graphics and give it to young audiences. Oh well, enough with trash-talking let's go to the real pros/cons
PROS;
-Music, It's random and suits the game. Calm. 9.5/10
-Graphics. They're not super next gen graphics, but simple that don't demand beefy computers. 9.5/10
-Art: Console art, or anything here, that's one of the best in the game. 10/10
-Story: Every console has been renamed, for example, Playstation is now Playsystem. The story is well fitting, amazing, and it can reach up to Playsystem 5, and Mbox Next, which have amazing Art. 10/10
-Mods: The community is making some amazing mods, to simple topic or researches mods, to mods that overhaul the game. I can say, this feature is really good, since it won't make you be bored of that game. The game Runs in JavaScript and CSS. I'm a modder myself as well. The new update will introduce workshop Support, which is making this feature much more amazing. There's even a MultiplayerMod. 10/10

CONS;
- Playtime is around 6-8 hours in 30 years, and 10-12 in 42 years, the game ends too quick.
- There won't be any more content updates, because the developers left that feature to modders.

Conclusion:
I don't think that the Cons here win. I find the Pros really good so that's why I bought this game. I'm often in the forums, which are almost dead, but we hope after the 1.5.0 update, people may come over to the forums. There are quite good impressive mods in the forums if you want to check them out. Just Google greenheartgames forums.

reviewText:
Game Dev Tycoon. A simple, yet great game. Let me get started.
Firstly, this game is amazing because:
You can mae your own games, your own consoles, complete contracts, work with publishers, make genre/topic combinations, and more. You can also make a Military/Action game, call it Call of Duty with medium graphics and give it to young audiences. Oh well, enough with trash-talking let's go to the real pros/cons
PROS;
-Music, It's random and suits the game. Calm. 9.5/10
-Graphics. They're not super next gen graphics, but simple that don't demand beefy computers. 9.5/10
-Art: Console art, or anything here, that's one of the best in the game. 10/10
-Story: Every console has been renamed, for example, Playstation is now Playsystem. The story is well fitting, amazing, and it can reach up to Playsystem 5, and Mbox Next, which have amazing Art. 10/10
-Mods: The community is making some amazing mods, to simple topic or researches mods, to mods that overhaul the game. I can say, this feature is really good, since it won't make you be bored of that game. The game Runs in JavaScript and CSS. I'm a modder myself as well. The new update will introduce workshop Support, which is making this feature much more amazing. There's even a MultiplayerMod. 10/10

CONS;
- Playtime is around 6-8 hours in 30 years, and 10-12 in 42 years, the game ends too quick.
- There won't be any more content updates, because the developers left that feature to modders.

Conclusion:
I don't think that the Cons here win. I find the Pros really good so that's why I bought this game. I'm often in the forums, which are almost dead, but we hope after the 1.5.0 update, people may come over to the forums. There are quite good impressive mods in the forums if you want to check them out. Just Google greenheartgames forums.

reviewText: This game is enjoyable for it's genre. While playing, you, the creator of your own game development studio needs to work your way up to the development of big titles. Starting in the 80's with limited platforms on which to create games, as time goes on you take a trip down memory lane, creating titles to be released on parody consoles that mirror those that seem like a distant memory now. As far as a tychoon game goes, this one is addictive and forces you to be mindful of the components that run your business (such as althernate ways to earn income) as well as being strategic. The hardest part of this game is knowing what genres work best on what platforms, and for what audience. It's also tough because you need to consistently research new information and techniques to further develop your marketing skills and create new engines to release your games on. While tricky at points, this game is still enjoy able and will definitely find a way to take up all your time for an evening if you're not careful.

reviewText:
I use to not really be in to games like this.  When I heard about Game Dev Tycoon, I added it to my wishlist because I wanted to see how it was.  It finally came on sale during the Winter Sales, and along with almost 30 other games, I bought it.  It took me a while before I decided to download it, and an hour into the game, I realized it was a mistake to wait that long.

I am actually the co-writer and a voice actor of one of my friends' projects they are woking on.  I've always been interested by video games.  After starting it, I see you start with 5 genres and 4 or so types of games.  You had to do research to unlock more genres.  There was also the very immersive engine builder.  It covered soooooo many things that you would actually have had to do if you were building your own engine.  But most of all, my favorite part of this game is the extreme care and precision in following gaming history.  All of the consoles are based off of the game consoles we've actually had, along with accurate facts for each and every one of them.  While they are missing some game consoles (like the NeoGeo), the developers covered everything important.

Since this is actually realistic and tailored with real gaming history, I will add that rating as well.

Gaming History Friendly-9.5/10
Detail of the In Game Mechanics-9.5/10
Realism-8.5/10
Graphics-N/A (not applicable) | N/I (not important).  Yes, this is actually one of those games where graphics don't matter.  Accordingly, I won't factor in Graphics to the final rating.
Music-6/10
Replay Value-9/10

Overall Value-8.5
Recommended buy price-$12 USD or cheaper.  Worth the price.

Note: I do not recommend modding this game, though it is supported.  Beware that installing/uninstalling mods can corrupt your data.  They also really don't help enhance the game, either.

reviewText:
My goodness, I had no idea how hooked to this game I would be when I picked it up.  I purchased Game Dev Tycoon and a handful of other games that were on sale and I ended up trying this one first and did not stop until I had completed it.  This is hands down one of the most addictive games I have ever played, and I really hope there will be a sequel to it.

Constantly trying to find the best matches to make the best games, while at the same time being confused when certain combinations did not work.  Not only is the gameplay fun and addictive, but you also get a bit of a nostalgia kick seeing all of the consoles and handhelds released throughout the years while playing through the game.  Crazy to think how much has happened in gaming since it all started.

I highly recommend this game.  While it is a casual game, any one who loves any kind of game should be able to start this up and have a good time playing it.

11/10

reviewText:
I had only heard of this game through the wacky press coverage of the punishing of pirates for it. It didn't sound like the time of game I would enjoy, so at the time I gave it a pass. When I saw it on sale, I was bored, so I figured it'd kill a few hours, for a couple of dollars, so it'd likely be worth a buy, so I did.

I can't quite explain why, but on the first day, I played it for almost the entire time I was awake, and most of the next day too. It's quirky, it's a weird concept, and I noticed on the second day that IT HAS MOD SUPPORT (although not through steam workshop). Even now, I'm still confused with myself over what exactly draws me to keep playing it.

All I can say for sure is that it is a lot of fun. Knowing how much fun it is now, I wish I had purchased it a long time ago.

reviewText:
What sums up this game? Short and Sweet. Game Dev Tycoon is a very casual yet quite addictive game. You take the role of a game developer, trying to get by, making games for a living. This sprouts (Sprouts sells too much healthy food :() into a bigger company, leaving you responsible for your employees, as they can get tired from overworking. It has a simple but neat way of creating your games. And once you finish, that casual vibe turns into utter suspense as you wait for the reviews to come in. It has many Genre's you can explore with, many combinations, and many technologies you can research to make your games bigger, bolder, and better.

Overall I give this game a solid 7/10. Go try it if you want a neat little game to play.

I made a company named Activision, made Call of duty, and got a 1.75/10. Totally realistic :D

reviewText: The game is pretty simple. You choose a game topic and a corresponding genre for it which you think results in a good combination. Next, you try to find out what areas to prioritize in game development that goes well with your chosen topic ang genre. Don't try to look at cheat sheets! Slowly master a topic/genre combination by making sequels. That is really what the game is about. Not a lot of replayability though as once you finish the campaign, the only thing that you may want to get are the achievements. Definitely pick it up when it's on sale and when you don't mind playing a short game.

reviewText: I bought this in the holiday sale for practically peanuts. I got hooked straight away and realised I got myself more then a bargain! I advise you to start a game and learn the basics. You will more than likely go bankrupt quite early on but you will be much better prepared for your second attempt. I failed again at my second attempt so then got the cheat mod to just stop me from going bankrupt. On my third playthrough I reinvented SEGA and made them into the number one game/console development company. Theres a lot of fun in recreating your favourite games and turning them into AAA 10/10 titles. So far it has been 16 hours very well spent. The reviews I read here made me buy this game, You wont regret doing the same thing!

reviewText:
Great game overall, well worth the $2 I paid it for it when it was on sale a while ago

I rarely write reviews but this game is actually really fun to play and considering it came from an indie developer I'm very impressed.

Here's a list of pros and cons.

Pros

Simple and easy to understand (tool tips pop up and explain most things, basic 'help' section also)
Multiple consoles to develop for (pretty much all of them, missing a few smaller ones but still great)
Lots of topics and genres to build for
Progress from small slummy garage to sexy building
Towards the end there is lots of do and research (the R&D towards the end is done very well)
Some similarities to other dev games, but really becomes very unique towards the middle to the end (you can specialise your workers etc)
Lots of other cool stuff along the way
Cons (Not really negatives, just small things that could be improved)
Time passes really quickly, would have been good if there was a speed slider, or if it took a little longer for the weeks to pass
Your workers are skilled in development / technology but it seems to me that only 'graphics' is the only skill that utilises the technology attribute (Maybe I just don't quite understand who to assign to different tasks on medium / large games)
Sometimes its hard to see what will be successful by combining topics and genres (it does tell you it may be a good combination after you selected what you want, given you have researched it, however it would be good if you didn't have to go back and forth to select and reselect things
Lots of trial and error in discovering what works, would be good to actually research into a topic to see if the market will like it
Overall great game!
voteText: 1 person found this review helpful
